content.webTitle: Crystal Palace manager Neil Warnock praises ‘revelation’ Jason Puncheon

fields.headline: Crystal Palace manager Neil Warnock praises ‘revelation’ Jason Puncheon
fields.bodyText: Eight months ago, Jason Puncheon stepped up to take a penalty for Crystal Palace. Little did he know that those next few seconds, which culminated in him sending his effort high over the Tottenham crossbar, would lead to some over-cooked criticism from Neil Warnock and an unseemly argument between the two, some of it carried out on Twitter. Now, wouldn’t you know it, with the pair reunited at Palace, Warnock is talking in glowing terms about the player. But first, the argument. Warnock was working as a pundit on TalkSport in March when he brought up Puncheon’s miss. He said on the radio station: “There’s no way I would’ve trusted him with a penalty. You’ve got to have somebody a little bit more cool, and he’s not like that, Jason. He can whack a 35-yard free-kick in here and there but a penalty, with all the pressure on him at a place like White Hart Lane – not in a million years for me.” Puncheon responded with some tweets that he swiftly deleted. Warnock knew Puncheon well as he signed him on loan at QPR in 2011, although he clearly did not rate him that highly. In four months at Loftus Road, he only made two appearances, as a substitute, which perhaps explains those comments. However, when Warnock was appointed manager of Palace at the end of last month, he thought Puncheon was on his way out of the club. Warnock said: “I was told he was going to ask to leave, before my first day. So I was waiting for him to ask but we just had a quick chat, only a 10-minute chat and he was brilliant really. I said I was pleased with him, I said he had been fantastic the last couple of years. He’s been a revelation for me, him and [Yannick] Bolasie.” Bolasie was as effective on the left wing as Puncheon was on the right. In the second half, Bolasie’s cross forced Kasper Schmeichel into conceding a corner that was taken by Puncheon. Scott Dann headed it goalwards and Fraizer Campbell, bought for £900,000 from Cardiff City in July, flicked his shot past Schmeichel for his second goal in as many games. Three minutes later, Bolasie was hauled down by Wes Morgan outside the penalty area, Puncheon curled in the free-kick and Mile Jedinak glanced his header inside Schmeichel’s far post. Game over and a second consecutive convincing league victory for Palace, who won 3-2 at Everton last Sunday. Palace’s three-man strikeforce was too much for Leicester City to cope with. Six days after their thrilling 5-3 defeat of Manchester United, this was a poor follow-up performance by Nigel Pearson’s men. Jamie Vardy and Leonardo Ulloa were not the same threat that they posed to Louis van Gaal’s defence and Leicester’s vulnerability to set pieces was exposed. Pearson, never one – on the surface at least – to swing between emotional highs and lows, was measured in his assessment of his team. “I’ll take time to reflect on the performance because there are certain things that clearly we’ve got to improve on,” he said. “But for the most part the performances so far have been very encouraging and we’ve had some positive results because of it.” This was not one of them. Man of the match Yannick Bolasie (Crystal Palace)
